title: 108_hr4955
content: The Act may be cited as the "Children's Listbroker Privacy Act" and includes findings. Congress finds that commercial list brokers routinely sell detailed information on children, including names, addresses, ages, and other data for marketing purposes. This data is available on children as young as two years old, allowing marketers to target specific demographics. Marketing databases can be large, covering millions of children and include information on ethnicity, family income, hobbies, and interests. The annual spending on marketing to children is estimated at $12 billion. Several Federal statutes, such as the No Child Left Behind Act, Children's Online Privacy Protection Act, and Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act, restrict the collection and disclosure of information about children or students. However, Federal law does not significantly limit the commercial sale or resale of such data when collected outside the scope of these statutes. This creates an economic incentive to find new ways to collect and sell children's information, potentially circumventing existing laws. Marketers and list brokers use various means to gather data about children, including names and addresses. Restriction on sale or purchase of children's personal information. It is unlawful to sell or purchase personal information about a child without parental consent or certification. Certification is required for the sale of personal information about a child, stating the purpose of use and prohibiting marketing to or by the purchaser. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT. The Act will be enforced by the Federal Trade Commission, with exceptions for enforcement by certain other agencies like the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency for national banks and the Federal Reserve System for member banks. The Act also includes regulations for oversight of various financial institutions, such as commercial lending companies owned or controlled by foreign banks, banks insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and savings associations with deposits insured by the FDIC. The Act is enforced by various agencies including the Federal Trade Commission, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, and the Federal Reserve System. Any entity that violates provisions of the Act is subject to penalties and privileges under the Federal Trade Commission Act. Nothing in the Act limits the authority of the Commission under other laws. SEC. 5. ACTIONS BY STATES. The attorney general of a State can bring a civil action in federal court to address practices violating the Act, seeking injunctions, compliance, damages, or other relief for residents of the State. Before filing an action under the Act, the attorney general of the State must provide written notice and a copy of the complaint to the Commission. There is an exemption if the attorney general determines it is not feasible to provide notice before filing the action. The attorney general of a State must notify the Commission and provide a copy of the complaint when filing an action. The Commission has the right to intervene in the action and be heard on any matter that arises, as well as file a petition for appeal. (c) Construction.--For civil actions under subsection (a), State attorney generals can conduct investigations, administer oaths, and compel witnesses. The Commission has exclusive rights during its actions, preventing States from filing separate actions. Venue for actions under subsection (a) is in a U.S. district court. In civil actions under subsection (a), venue for the action is in a U.S. district court meeting applicable requirements. Process can be served in any district where the defendant is an inhabitant or can be found. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "child" refers to an individual under 16 years old, "Commission" means the Federal Trade Commission, and "express consent" is defined as affirmative permission given in writing or electronically after being informed of the purpose. Personal information is identifiable information about an individual, including their name. Marketing involves communication to promote the purchase or use of a commercial product or service. A parent includes a legal guardian. Personal information includes identifiable details about an individual such as name, address, email, phone number, Social Security number, or any information that can identify a specific person. The terms "purchase", "sell", and "sale" in section 3 encompass the exchange of the right to use personal information, regardless of limitations, characterization of the transaction, or the form of consideration. The Act will become effective 6 months after enactment.
